title.value: Estimating causal effects with optimization-based methods: A review and empirical comparison
title.justification: This is the title of the research paper provided in the document.
title.quote: Estimating causal effects with optimization-based methods: A review and empirical comparison

extractions.description: The paper reviews and empirically compares various optimization-based methods for estimating causal effects when randomized controlled trials or natural experiments are not feasible. It discusses how these methods balance the distributions of covariates between treated and control groups to eliminate bias and provides comparative results against other causal inference methods.

type.justification: The paper provides empirical comparisons of several optimization-based methods for estimating causal effects using data from the 2016 ACIC competition.
type.quote: We now discuss some of these results in more detail. First, note that the ebal and sbw methods fail to estimate the SATT on 3187 datasets, in contrast to the other four optimization-based methods. [...] In particular, the best method in Table 6 is a mixed method that uses the estimated propensity score as an additional covariate in the regression model of the response.

name.justification: The primary focus of the paper is on methods for estimating causal effects, which is a core aspect of causal inference.
name.quote: First, for the lay researchers, we provide an overview of the scattered causal inference literature.

name.justification: The paper extensively discusses and compares methods based on optimization for estimating causal effects.
name.quote: we present an overview of the causal inference literature and describe in more detail the optimization-based causal inference methods, provide a comparative analysis of the prevailing optimization-based methods

name.justification: The paper mentions and includes machine learning methods for comparison, such as BART and other regression-based methods.
name.quote: Finally, we decided to also test the Bayesian additive regression trees (BART) method (Hill, 2011) with the default parameters to check whether we would be able to attain the results in the 2016 ACIC competition.

name.justification: The empirical comparison in the paper uses 7700 datasets from the 2016 ACIC competition.
name.quote: It is common to use constructed observational studies for comparative purposes. [...] In this paper, we use this latter alternative. In particular, we use the 7700 datasets of the 2016 ACIC competition.

referenced_paper_title.value: Automated versus do-it-yourself methods for causal inference: Lessons learned from a data analysis competition
referenced_paper_title.justification: The authors reference the 2016 ACIC competition data for their empirical comparisons.
referenced_paper_title.quote: These datasets are available through a R package at https://github.com/vdorie/aciccomp/tree/master/2016.

name.justification: The empirical comparisons and implementations of methods were executed using R.
name.quote: These optimization-based methods are executed using their default parameters on R 4.0.2 to demonstrate their usefulness when directly used by an applied researcher.

referenced_paper_title.value: R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing
referenced_paper_title.justification: R is used extensively for running the empirical comparisons in the paper.
referenced_paper_title.quote: These optimization-based methods are executed using their default parameters on R 4.0.2
